abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Energy for Rural
            Transformation (ERT) Project for Uganda were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: a clear lesson emerging from phase one of
            the ERT is the need to undertake a careful assessment of the
            potential for private sector investment in rural energy/
            renewable energy, including identifying barriers, needed
            incentives, and/or risk mitigation measures to enhance this
            potential. Participation of the private sector in phase one
            in renewable energy power generation for sale to the grid
            was satisfactory but was poor in access projects via
            main-grid extension, the project's largest investment
            component. Project design needs to take into account
            existing capacities of all ministries and public agencies
            involved in implementation, including at the community
            level; training and capacity building also need to be
            provided to operate and maintain projects. Having a
            field-based member in the Bank's supervision team,
            speaking the local language with a detailed knowledge of the
            country's rural areas, is effective and helpful in
            project implementation, especially for dealing with issues
            on a real-time basis. It is also helpful in ensuring that
            the Bank team has a close relationship with the many
            stakeholders in a project of this kind. The complex
            procurement packages required seasoned Bank project
            procurement staff to be in place during project preparation
            rather than later in the project implementation period.
            Currently, there is limited supply of long-term development
            finance (on terms beyond five years), due to the mismatch
            between the requirements of long-term lending, and the time
            profile of commercial banks liabilities. This constraint
            needs to be rectified. Uganda also needs to develop further
            strategies to attract more foreign investment for rural energy.
